begin.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: In the third year, students begin the study of classical Chinese.
The president begins talks with the prime minister tonight.
She began to feel a sense of panic.
begin.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if something begins, or you begin something, it starts to happen or exist from a particular time
begin.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: It was the coldest winter since records began.
begin.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if you begin with something or begin by doing something, this is the first thing you do
begin.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Shall we begin with a prayer?
I’ll begin by thanking you all for being here tonight.
begin.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: if a book, film, or word begins with something, it starts with a particular event or letter
begin.translation[0].definitions[3].note: In everyday English, people usually say start rather than begin:
Not many English names start with X.
begin.translation[0].definitions[4].exam: ‘Ladies and gentlemen, ’ he began. ‘I am delighted to be here.’
begin.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0: Begin belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
begin.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1: In this sentence, ‘the meeting’ is the object of begin
begin.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2: In this sentence, ‘the meeting’ is the subject of begin
